questions.question: A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lyingunconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for thefollowing findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?

A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urinationof two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make yoususpect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.explanation: White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (puscasts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules.The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate. It is foundin both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specificfinding.Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterialgrowth. It is seen in renal TB.

questions.question: What is the most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis?
questions.explanation: The most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis is Escherichia coli.The organisms that cause acute pyelonephritis include:•⚫ E. coli• Proteus• Klebsiella.Enterobacter species•Mycobacteria-caseating granulomatous inflammation• Fungi - non-caseating granulomatous inflammation• Viruses (CMV and adenovirus) - immunocompromised people808

questions.question: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of which of the following conditions?801
questions.explanation: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis.Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are:• Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroidcolloid (thyroidization)• Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla••Periglomerular fibrosisSecondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring hasoccurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux

questions.question: A pathologist noted the following microscopic finding while examining a slide of a kidney.What is the likely cause?COCO
questions.explanation: The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resemblingthyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.Thyroidization - Chronic Pyelonephritis8809Thyroidization - Chronic PyelonephritisDilated tubulesFORFlattened epitheliumCasts like thyroid colloidOption A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis.Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates.Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.

questions.question: All of the following patients are at risk of developing renal papillary necrosis except:

options.A: A 14-year-old girl being treated for thalassemia major
options.B: A 60-year-old man with longstanding diabetes mellitus
options.C: A 46-year-old man with a history of analgesic abuse
options.D: A 24-year-old woman identified to have sickle cell trait802

questions.explanation: Necrotizing papillitis or acute papillary necrosis is not associated with thalassemia.Major causes of acute papillary necrosis include• Diabetes mellitus• Sickle cell disease or trait•••Analgesic abuse nephropathyObstruction by calculi• Focally in renal tuberculosis

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of flank pain and fever with chills.CECT abdomen showed dilated and enlarged left renal pelvis with the multiloculated calycesand resection of the kidney was done. The gross specimen showed large yellowish-orangenodules. Histological examination revealed foamy macrophages. Which of the following isassociated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical features and histological findings are suggestive of xanthogranulomatouspyelonephritis. It is associated with Proteus infection and obstructive uropathy.Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritischaracterized by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells,lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells.The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused withrenal cell carcinoma. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyces showinga multiloculated appearance referred to as the bear paw sign.810Xanthogranulomatous PyelonephritisXanthogranulomatous PyelonephritisLipid-laden macrophages

questions.question: Which of the following do not result in granular contracted kidneys?
questions.explanation: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and amyloidosis cause enlarged kidneys.Causes of contracted kidneys:•Symmetric• Chronic glomerulonephritis•Benign nephrosclerosis•Asymmetric• Chronic pyelonephritisCauses of enlarged kidneys:811•Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis• Amyloidosis•Polycystic kidney disease•Hydronephrosis (bilateral obstruction)The following image shows the gross appearance in benign nephrosclerosis illustrating the fine,leathery granularity of the surface.

questions.question: Which of the following findings is not associated with malignant hypertension?1234803
questions.explanation: Image 4 shows a leather-grain appearance, which is seen in benign nephrosclerosis.Features of malignant hypertension:• Flea bitten kidney - small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface, leading to a mottledappearance•Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles - cytologic detail is lost and the vessel wall takes on a smudgyeosinophilic appearance due to fibrin deposition• Onion-skinning (hyperplastic arterioles) - intimal thickening with the fine concentric layering ofcollagen & smooth muscles812Flea bitten kidneyOnion skinning appearanceFibrinoid necrosis813Leather grain appearance of KidneyThe differential diagnosis for flea-bitten kidney includes:•Polyarteritis nodosa•Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE)• Malignant hypertension

questions.question: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome can be caused by all except:
questions.explanation: Deficiency of ADAMTS13 leads to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).Two common pathogenetic triggers of thrombotic microangiopathies are:• Endothelial injury - HUS• Excessive platelet activation and aggregation - TTPTypical HUS5-10 days afterdiarrhealillnesSE.coli O157:H7orShigella dysenteriaetype IShiga-liketoxinsproduced causeendothelialdamage. This leads to platelet activation and thrombi.Atypical HUSMutation in genes encoding complement regulatory proteinUncontrolledactivationof thecomplementsystem due to:Antiphospholipid antibodies Pregnancy complicationsOCPsScleroderma

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy is brought with blood in the urine. His mother says he had bloody diarrhea,fever, and vomiting 10 days ago. His BP is 130/90 mm Hg, and he is jaundiced. Investigationsreveal a platelet count of 50,000 cells/cu mm, BUN of 35mg/dl, and creatinine of 3.5mg/dl.Which of the following cells would you expect to see in the peripheral smear?
questions.explanation: 814The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is characterized by thepresence of schistocytes in peripheral smear. It indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

questions.question: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with which of the following casts?
questions.explanation: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile.In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may beimpaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevatedbilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephronsegments.

questions.question: 804A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of thekidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

options.A: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.explanation: The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomalrecessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encodingpolycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renalparenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and,therefore, have variable lining epithelia.The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include:• Hepatic cysts most common• Seminal vesicle cysts can result in infertility-• Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma• Pancreatic cysts• Splenic cysts• Intracranial berry aneurysms⚫ Subarachnoid hemorrhages••• Mitral valve prolapseThere are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association betweenADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in theincidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the polycystin gene?

options.A: Polycystin-1 is most commonly involved in ADPKD
options.B: Polycystin-2 is a calcium ion channel
options.C: Mutation in polycystin-2 causes more severe form of ADPKD
options.D: Polycystin-1 is involved in cell interactions

questions.explanation: The polycystin-2 mutation is less commonly involved and less severe.815Polycystin-1 is encoded by the PKD1 gene located on chromosome 16p13.3. It is expressed intubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron. It contains domains that areusually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. Mutations in PKD1 account for about85% of cases of ADPKD (autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) and it causes a moresevere form of the disease.Polycystin-2 is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubulesand in many extrarenal tissues. It functions as a Ca2+ cation channel. Overall, it causes a lesssevere form of ADPKD disease.

questions.question: What is the most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidneydisease?
questions.explanation: The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD) is the liver.40% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one toseveral cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts arederived from the biliary epithelium.Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few casereports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cystshas not been proved.

questions.question: In patients with ADPKD, the mutated genes are located on which chromosomes?
questions.explanation: The genes mutated in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are located onchromosomes 16 and 4.This condition occurs due to mutations of the PKD1 gene (chromosome 16) and PKD2 gene (onchromosome 4). These genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins respectively.

questions.question: Mutations in fibrocystin are seen in which condition?
questions.explanation: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1gene on chromosome 6p21-p23 which encodes fibrocystin.The gene is highly expressed in adult and fetal kidneys and also in the liver andpancreas. Fibrocystin has been localized to the primary cilium of tubular cells.The serious manifestations of ARPKD are usually present at birth, and may cause death by renalfailure. The following gross findings are seen:• Enlarged kidneys with smooth external appearance•Spongelike appearance due to numerous small cysts in the cortex and medulla•• Dilated elongated channels at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing themedulla and cortex816On microscopic examination, there is cylindrical or, less commonly, saccular dilation of allcollecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells. In almost all cases, the liver has cysts associatedwith portal fibrosis and proliferation of the portal bile ducts, termed congenital hepatic fibrosis.

questions.question: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.

questions.question: A routine urine examination of a 46-year-old woman shows thorn-apple crystals. Past historyis significant for constipation and longstanding use of laxatives. What is the likelycomposition of these crystals?
questions.explanation: Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregularprojections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.

questions.question: In patients with chronic kidney disease, what type of casts are seen?
questions.explanation: Broad casts are seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). They are also known as renalfailure casts.Broad casts are defined as those with a diameter 2-6 times that of normal casts. They indicatechronically damaged tubules or collecting ducts. They indicate a poor prognosis.817
